abstract.text: We present a combination of measurements of the top quark mass by the D0 experiment in the lepton+jets and dilepton channels.
We use all the data collected in Run I (1992)(1993)(1994)(1995)(1996) at √ s = 1.8 TeV and Run II (2001-2011) at √ s = 1.96 TeV of the Tevatron pp collider, corresponding
to integrated luminosities of 0.1 fb −1 and 9.7 fb −1 , respectively.
The combined result is: mt = 174.95 ± 0.40 (stat) ± 0.64 (syst) GeV = 174.95 ± 0.75 GeV.

body_text.text: J. Zennamo, 62 T.G. Zhao, 41 B. Zhou, 56 J. Zhu, 56 M. Zielinski, 63 D. Zieminska, 49 and L. Zivkovic p14 (The D0 Collaboration * )

The top quark is the heaviest known elementary particle with a mass approximately twice that of the electroweak vector bosons, and factor of 1.4 larger than that of the more recently discovered Higgs boson [1].
Within the standard model (SM), this large mass arises from a large Yukawa coupling (≈ 0.9) to the Higgs field.

Consequently, loops involving the top quark contribute significantly to electroweak quantum corrections, and therefore a precise measurement of the top quark mass, m t , provides a means to test the consistency of the SM.

Furthermore, the precise values of both the mass of the Higgs boson and the Yukawa coupling of the top quark may play a critical role in the history and stability of the universe (see e.g., Ref. [2]).
The top quark was discovered in 1995 by the CDF and D0 experiments during Run I (1992)(1993)(1994)(1995)(1996) of the Fermilab Tevatron pp collider at √ s = 1.8 TeV [3,4].
Run II (2001-2011) at √ s = 1.96 TeV followed, providing a factor of ≈ 150 more top-antitop quark pairs than Run I, and far more precise measurements of m t .

Using tt events produced in the D0 detector [5][6][7][8], we have measured m t in different decay channels [9][10][11][12][13][14][15] using the full integrated luminosity of Run I ( L dt = 0.1 fb −1 ) and Run II ( L dt = 9.7 fb −1 ).
This article reports the combination of these direct top quark mass measurements.

Direct measurements of the top quark mass have also been performed by the CDF experiment (see e.g. Ref. [16]) at the Tevatron, and by the ATLAS (see e.g. Ref. [17]) and CMS (see e.g. Ref. [18]) experiments at the CERN LHC.
In 2012, the Tevatron experiments combined their measurements in Ref.
[19] with the result m t = 173.18±0.94 GeV.
In 2014, a preliminary combination of ATLAS, CDF, CMS, and D0 measurements [20] yielded m t = 173.34 ± 0.76 GeV.
Both combinations are by now outdated as they do not include the latest and more precise measurements, in particular, the final D0 Run II measurements discussed in this article.
The top quark mass is a fundamental free parameter of the SM.
However, its definition depends on the scheme of theoretical calculations used for the perturbative expansion in quantum chromodynamics (QCD).
The inputs to the combination presented in this article are the direct measurements calibrated using Monte Carlo (MC) simulations.
Hence, the measured mass corresponds to the MC mass parameter.

However, because of the presence of long range effects in QCD, the relationship beween the MC mass and other mass definitions, such as the pole mass or the mass in the modified minimal subtraction (MS) scheme, is not well established and has been subject to debate for many years (see e.g., Ref. [21] and references therein).
A recent work obtains a difference of +0.6 GeV between the MC mass and the pole mass in the context of an e + e − → tt simulation with an uncertainty of 0.3 GeV [22].
Further studies are needed to produce a similar estimate in the context of pp → tt production.
In Ref.
[23], we extracted the pole mass of the top quark from the measured tt cross section [24].

However, due to the ambiguity between the MC and pole mass, the difficulty of properly assessing correlations between systematic uncertainties, and the large uncertainty of the pole mass measurement, the latter is not part of the combination presented in this article.

This article is structured as follows: we first summarize the input measurements; we subsequently present the combination of Run II dilepton measurements, which provides one of the inputs to the D0 combination; we then discuss the different uncertainty categories and their correlations, and conclude with the final combined result.
II.
DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS
To measure the top quark mass, we use pp → tt events and assume that the top and antitop quark masses are equal [25][26][27][28].
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Within the SM, the top quark decays into a W boson and a b quark almost 100% of the time.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Different channels arise from the possible decays of the pair of W bosons: i.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The "dilepton" channel (ℓℓ ′ ) corresponds to events (≈ 4.5% of the total) where both W bosons decay into electrons or muons.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: This channel is quite free from background but has a small yield.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The background is mainly due to Z+jets production, but also receives contributions from diboson (W W , W Z, ZZ), W +jets, and multijet production.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: ii.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The "lepton+jets" channel (ℓ + jets) corresponds to events (≈ 30% of the total) where one W boson decays into qq ′ and the other into an electron or a muon and a neutrino.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: This channel has a moderate yield and a background arising from W +jets production, Z+jets production, and multijet processes.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: iii.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The "all jets" channel (≈ 46% of the total) has events in which both W bosons decay to qq ′ that evolve into jets.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The yield is high, but the background from multijet production is very large.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: iv.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The "tau channel" (≈ 20% of the total) arises from events in which at least one of the W bosons decays into τ ν τ .
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: As the decays τ → hadrons + ν τ are difficult to distinguish from QCD jets, it is not exploited for the top quark mass measurement.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: How-ever, the τ → ℓν ℓ ν τ decays provide contributions to the ℓℓ ′ and ℓ + jets channels.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The high mass of the top quark means that the decay products tend to have high transverse momenta (p T ) relative to the beam axis and large angular separations.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Reconstructing and identifying tt events requires reconstruction and identification of high p T electrons, muons, and jets, and the measurement of the imbalance in transverse momentum in each event ( p T ) due to escaping neutrinos.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: In addition, identifying b jets is an effective way of improving the purity of the selections.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Good momentum resolution is required for all these objects, and the jet energy scale (JES) has to be known with high precision.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: In the Run II ℓ + jets measurements, the uncertainty in the JES is reduced by performing an in situ calibration, which exploits the W → qq ′ decay by requiring the mass of the corresponding dijet system to be consistent with the mass of the W boson (80.4 GeV).
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: This calibration, determined using light-quark jets (including charm jets), is applied to jets of all flavors associated with tt decay.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: It is then propagated to the Run II ℓℓ ′ measurements.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The input measurements of m t for the presented combination are shown in Table I, and consist of measurements performed during Run I and Run II in the ℓℓ ′ and ℓ + jets channels using the full data sets.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: D0 also measured the top quark mass using the "all jets" channel in Run I [29]; however, this measurement is not considered in the combination because its uncertainty is large and some subcomponents of the systematic uncertainty are not available.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Just as in Run I, two ℓℓ ′ mass measurements were performed in Run II using a neutrino weighting [12] technique (NW) and a matrix element method (ME) [13].
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: We discuss their combination in the following section.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: To combine the m t measurements, we use the Best Linear Unbiased Estimate (BLUE) [30], assuming Gaussian uncertainties, both for the ℓℓ ′ Run II and the final D0 combinations.
body_text.section: II. DECAY CHANNELS AND INPUT MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: III.
COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS
In the ℓℓ ′ channel, the presence of two undetected neutrinos with high p T makes it impossible to fully reconstruct the kinematics of the final state.
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: To overcome this problem, we use two methods in Run II.
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The NW measurement [12] is based on a weight function for each event which is computed by comparing the x-and y-components of the observed p T and the hypothesized p T components of the neutrinos, integrating over the neutrino pseudorapidities [31].
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The maximum weight value indicates the most likely value of m t in that event.
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The first and second moments of this function are retained as the event-by-event variables sensitive to m t .
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Their distributions in MC events are used to form two-dimensional templates that depend upon the value of m t .
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The templates are compared to the data to extract m t .
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: The ME [13] TABLE I: Summary of the input measurements to the combination.
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: We indicate the method used to extract the mass of the top quark from the data (see the corresponding references for further details).
body_text.section: III. COMBINATION OF RUN II DILEPTON MEASUREMENTS

body_text.text: Period

Channel  [14,15] measurement uses per-event probability densities, based on the reconstructed kinematic information, obtained by integrating over the differential cross sections for the processes contributing to the observed events, using leading order matrix elements for the tt production process and accounting for detector resolution.
body_text.section: Period

body_text.text: The unmeasured neutrino momentum components are integrated out in this computation.
body_text.section: Period

body_text.text: The probability densities from all data events are combined to form a likelihood as a function of m t , which is then maximized to determine m t .
body_text.section: Period

body_text.text: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation
The statistical uncertainties of the individual NW and ME measurements are given in Table II.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: Both measurements are carried out using the same full D0 Run II data set, and similar selection criteria.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: Approximately 90% of the selected events are common to both analyses, and the measurements are therefore statistically correlated.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: We use an ensemble testing method to estimate these correlations.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: In the first step, we generate 1000 ensembles of simulated background and signal events with mass m t =172.5 GeV that pass the criteria of either the NW or the ME selection (see Refs. [12] and [13] for the detailed descriptions of the selections).
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: Each ensemble is generated with the same number of events as observed in data, using the expected signal and background fractions, separately for the ee, µµ, and eµ channels.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: The ME and NW ensembles are then obtained using the individual and slightly more restrictive selection criteria from each analysis, and m t is extracted following each of the analysis methods.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: From the two-dimensional distribution of the measured masses shown in Fig 1, we obtain a statistical correlation of ρ = 0.64 ± 0.02 between the two sets of measurements.
body_text.section: A. Statistical uncertainties and correlation

body_text.text: B. Systematic uncertainties in ℓℓ ′ channel
The differerent contributions to the systematic uncertainty considered in the NW and ME measurements are reported in Table II.

body_text.section: B. Systematic uncertainties in ℓℓ ′ channel

body_text.text: In situ light-jet calibration: The statistical uncertainty of the JES calibration, determined in the ℓ + jets measurement using light-quark jets, and propagated to the ℓℓ ′ measurements.
body_text.section: B. Systematic uncertainties in ℓℓ ′ channel

body_text.text: GeV
Response to b, q, and g jets: The part of the JES uncertainty that originates from differences in detector response among b, light-quark, and gluon jets.
body_text.section: GeV

body_text.text: Model for b jets: The part of the JES uncertainty that originates from uncertainties specific to the modeling of b jets.
body_text.section: GeV

body_text.text: This includes the dependence on semileptonic branching fractions and modeling of b quark fragmentation.
body_text.section: GeV

body_text.text: Light-jet response: The part of the JES uncertainty that affects all jets and includes the dependence of the calibration upon jet energy and pseudorapidity, and the effect of the out-of-cone calorimeter showering correction.
body_text.section: GeV

body_text.text: Jet energy resolution
Jet identification efficiency Multiple interaction model: The systematic uncertainty that arises from modeling the distribution of the number of interactions per Tevatron bunch crossing.
body_text.section: Jet energy resolution

body_text.text: b tag modeling: The uncertainty related to the modeling of the b tagging efficiency for b, c, and lightflavor jets in MC simulation relative to data.
body_text.section: Jet energy resolution

body_text.text: Electron energy resolution
Muon momentum resolution Lepton momentum scale: The uncertainty arising from the calibration of electron energy and muon momentum scales.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: Trigger efficiency: The uncertainties in the estimation of lepton-based trigger efficiencies.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: Higher-order corrections: The modeling of higherorder corrections in the simulation of tt samples, obtained from the difference between the next-toleading-order MC@NLO [32] and the leading-order ALPGEN [33] event generators.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: Initial and final state radiation: The uncertainty due to the modeling of initial and final state gluon radiation.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: Hadronization and underlying events: The uncertainty associated with the modeling of hadronization and the underlying event, estimated from the difference between different hadronization models.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: Color reconnection: The uncertainty due to the model of color reconnection.
body_text.section: Electron energy resolution

body_text.text: PDF:
The uncertainty from the choice of parton density functions.
body_text.section: PDF:

body_text.text: Transverse momentum of tt system: The uncertainty in the modeling of the distribution of the p T of the tt system.
body_text.section: PDF:

body_text.text: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:
The uncertainty associated with the production cross section for Z+bb and Z+cc relative to Z+jets events.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: Background from simulation: The systematic uncertainty on the MC background, which includes the uncertainty from detector effects and the theoretical cross section.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: It does not include the uncertainties on the ratios of Z+bb and Z+cc to Z+jets cross sections, which belong to the previous category.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: Background based on data: The uncertainties from the modeling of the multijet and W +jets backgrounds estimated using data.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: Template statistics: In the NW measurement, this uncertainty arises from the statistical fluctations of individual bins in signal and background templates.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: In the ME measurement, there is no such uncertainty as there is no template used to fit the data.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: Calibration method: The calibration for both ME and NW measurements is determined using an ensemble testing method.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: We generate pseudo-experiments with the same number of events as observed in data, using MC events for signal and both MC and databased samples for backgrounds.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: Ensembles at different top quark mass hypotheses are generated to determine a linear relation between the uncorrected measurement and the actual MC mass, i.e., to determine slope and offset parameters.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: The uncertainty in the calibration method arises from the uncertainty in the slope and offset parameters due to the limited size of the MC and data-based samples.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: All systematic uncertainties are considered as fully correlated between ME and NW except for the calibration method uncertainty, as the calibrations were performed using almost independent event samples.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: The differences between the ME and NW uncertainties reported in Table II are consistent with the expected statistical fluctuations in the various estimates.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: The fluctuations are ≈ 0.05-0.10 GeV, depending on the source, and their overall contributions are well below the total uncertainties.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: They therefore have a negligible impact on the overall uncertainties in the individual measurements and their combination.
body_text.section: Yield of vector boson + heavy flavor:

body_text.text: The result of the BLUE combination is m t = 173.50 ± 1.31 (stat) ± 0.84 (syst) GeV.

body_text.text: The breakdown of uncertainties is given in Table II.
body_text.section: C. ℓℓ ′ combination

body_text.text: The weights for the NW and ME measurements are 71% and 29%, respectively.
body_text.section: C. ℓℓ ′ combination

body_text.text: The NW and ME measurements agree with a χ 2 of 0.2 for one degree of freedom, corresponding to a probability of 65%.
body_text.section: C. ℓℓ ′ combination

body_text.text: As a test of stability, we change the statistical correlation between the two methods from 0.50 to 0.70 to conservatively cover the range of systematic and statistical uncertainty in its determination.
body_text.section: C. ℓℓ ′ combination

body_text.text: The resulting m t changes by less than 0.04 GeV.

body_text.text: This combination of the Run II ℓℓ ′ measurements is used as an input to the overall combination discussed in the next sections.

UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION
For the overall combination, the systematic uncertainties are grouped into sources of same or similar origin to form uncertainty categories.

body_text.text: We employ categories similar to those used in the Tevatron top quark mass combination [19] and use the same naming scheme.

body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: It is obtained from the difference between event samples generated using PYTHIA [38] with the Perugia 2011 tune and using PYTHIA with the Perugia 2011NOCR tune [39].
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: iv.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainty associated with the choice for modeling parton-shower, hadronization, and underlying event.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: It includes the changes observed when substituting PYTHIA for HERWIG [35,36] when modeling tt signal.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: v. The uncertainty associated with the choice of PDF used to generate the tt MC events.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: It is estimated in Run II by changing the 20 eigenvalues of the CTEQ6.1M PDF [40] within their uncertainties.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: In Run I, it was obtained by comparing CTEQ3M [41] with MRSA [42] for ℓℓ ′ , and CTEQ4M [43] with CTEQ5L [44] for ℓ + jets events.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: Background from theory: This systematic uncertainty on background originating from theory takes into account the uncertainty in modeling the background sources.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: It is correlated among all measurements in the same channel, and includes uncertainties on background composition, normalization, and distributions.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: Background based on data: This includes uncertainties associated with the modeling of multijet background in the ℓ + jets channel, and multijet and W +jets backgrounds in the ℓℓ ′ channel, which are estimated using data.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: This also includes the effects of trigger uncertainties determined from the data.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: Calibration method: The uncertainty arising from any source specific to a particular fitting method, includes effects such as the finite number of MC events available to calibrate each method.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: Table III summarizes the input measurements and their corresponding statistical and systematic uncertainties.
body_text.section: IV. UNCERTAINTY CATEGORIES IN THE OVERALL COMBINATION

body_text.text: V. CORRELATIONS
The following correlations are used to combine the measurements:
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: i.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties listed as 'statistical uncertainty', 'calibration method', and 'background based on data' are taken to be uncorrelated among the measurements.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: ii.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties in the 'in situ light-jet calibration' category are taken to be correlated among the Run II measurements since the ℓℓ ′ measurement uses the JES calibration determined in the ℓ + jets channel.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: iii.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties in 'response to b, q, and g jets', 'jet modeling', 'b tag modeling', 'multiple interaction model', and 'lepton modeling' are taken to be 100% correlated among Run II measurements.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: iv.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties in 'out-of-cone correction' and 'offset' categories are taken to be 100% correlated among Run I measurements.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: v. The uncertainties in 'model for b jets' and 'signal modeling' categories are taken to be 100% correlated among all measurements.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: vi.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties in 'light-jet response' are taken to be 100% correlated among the Run I and the Run II measurements, but uncorrelated between Run I and Run II.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: vii.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainties in 'background from theory' are taken to be 100% correlated among all measurements in the same channel.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: A summary of the correlations among the different systematic categories is shown in Table IV.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: Using the inputs from Table III and the correlations specified in Table IV, we obtain an overall matrix of correlation coefficients in Table V. III: Summary of measurements used to determine the D0 average mt. Integrated luminosity ( L dt) has units of fb −1 , and all other values are in GeV.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

ref_spans.text: Table III and the correlations specified in Table IV

body_text.text: The uncertainty categories and their correlations are described in Section IV.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: The total systematic uncertainty and the total uncertainty are obtained by adding the relevant contributions in quadrature.
body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.section: V. CORRELATIONS

body_text.text: VI.
RESULTS
We combine the D0 input measurements of Table III using the BLUE method.
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: The BLUE combination has IV: Summary of correlations among sources of uncertainty.

body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: D0 Run I

D0 Run II ℓ + jets ℓℓ ′ ℓ + jets ℓℓ ′ In situ light-jet calibration n/a n/a × × response to b, q, and g jets n/a n/a × × Model for b jets × × × × Light-jet response ⊗ ⊗ × × Out-of-cone correction × × n/a n/a Offset × × n/a n/a Jet modeling n/a n/a × × Multiple interactions model n/a n/a × × b tag modeling n/a n/a × × Lepton modeling n/a n/a × × Signal modeling × × × × Background from theory × ⊗ × ⊗ Background based on data n/a n/a 0 0 Calibration method 0 0 0 0 Statistical 0 0 0 0 a χ 2 of 2.5 for 3 degrees of freedom, corresponding to a probability of 47%.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The pulls and weights for each of the inputs obtained from the BLUE method are listed in Table VI.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: Here, the pull associated to each input value m i with uncertainty σ i is calculated as (mi−mt) √
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: , where σ 2 mt is the uncertainty in the combination, and indicates the degree of agreement of the input with the combined value.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The weight w i given to the input measurement m i is w i = 4 j=1 (Cov −1 ) ij /N , where Cov is the covariance matrix of the input measurements, and N is a normalization term ensuring 4 i=1 w i = 1.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The covariance matrix expressed in terms of the correlation coefficients between the measurements c ij (with the convention c ii = 0) is:
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: , where δ ij is the Kronecker δ.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: At first order in the correlation coefficients, its inverse is given by (Cov −1 ) ij = 1 σi 1 σj (δ ij − c ij ), so that the weight w i can be written as
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: being a normalization term.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: This expression shows that the weight for the Run I ℓℓ ′ measurement is negative mainly because the correlation with the Run II ℓ + jets measurement (0.07) is larger than the ratio of their uncertainties (0.76/12.7).
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The resulting combined value for the top quark mass is m t = 174.95 ± 0.40 (stat) ± 0.64 (syst) GeV.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: Adding the statistical and systematic uncertainties in quadrature yields a total uncertainty of 0.75 GeV, corresponding to a relative precision of 0.43% on the top quark mass.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The breakdown of the uncertainties is shown in Table VII.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The dominant sources of uncertainty are the statistical uncertainty, the JES calibration, which has statistical origin, and the modeling of the signal.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The total statistical and systematic uncertainties are reduced relative to the published D0 and CDF combination [19] due primarily to the latest and most accurate D0 ℓ+jets analysis [14,15].
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: As a test of stability, we vary the correlation of the dominant source of uncertainties, 'signal modeling', from 100% to 0%, first between Run I and Run II measurements, and in a second check between all measurements.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The combined value of m t does not change by more than 50 MeV, while the uncertainty changes by no more than 20 MeV.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: This is due to the fact that the Run II ℓ + jets measurement dominates the combination with a weight of 96%.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: Thus, the combination is not sensitive to the detailed description of the correlation of systematic uncertainties.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: Due to a much smaller total uncertainty resulting in the large weight for the ℓ+jets measurement, the improvement in the combined uncertainty relative to the individual ℓ+jets uncertainty is smaller than 10 MeV.
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: The input measurements and the resulting D0 average mass of the top quark are summarized in Fig. 2, along with the top quark pole mass extracted by D0 from the measurement of the tt cross section [23].
body_text.section: D0 Run I

body_text.text: VII.
SUMMARY
We have presented the combination of the measurements of the top quark mass in all D0 data.
body_text.section: VII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Taking into account the statistical and systematic uncertainties and their correlations, we find a combined average of m t = 174.95 ± 0.75 GeV.
body_text.section: VII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: This measurement with, a relative precision of 0.43%, constitutes the legacy Run I and Run II measurement of the top quark mass in the D0 experiment.
body_text.section: VII. SUMMARY

For comparison, we also show the preliminary 2014 world average of mt [20] which includes D0 Run II ℓℓ ′ and ℓ + jets measurements that are now superseded.

For the top quark pole mass extracted from the D0 cross section measurement, a 1.1 GeV theory uncertainty is included in the systematic uncertainty, and the statistical uncertainty is determined such as its relative contribution to the experimental uncertainty is the same as for the cross-section measurement.
